class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author" id="ab005"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="as005"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0005">O3-type NaTMO<sub>2</sub> (TM&nbsp;=&nbsp;transition metal) is highly anticipated as a cathode for sodium-ion batteries due to its high theoretical specific capacity and low cost. However, the irreversible phase transition during sodiation/desodiation and the Jahn-Teller effect induced by Mn<sup>3+</sup> have hindered its steps towards industrialization. Herein, we propose a doping strategy to enhance the structural stability of O3-type NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> through Zr doping. On the one hand, the Na<sup>+</sup> transport channels are broadened due to the enlarged layer spacing, which accelerates the kinetic processes. On the other hand, Zr doping maintains structural integrity, inhibiting the decay of the layered structure. As a result, the uniquely designed material NNFMZO-6000 exhibited a discharge specific capacity of 113.8&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 1&nbsp;C and a capacity retention of 67.54&nbsp;% after 200 cycles. This work presents an effective modification method to optimize the properties of O3-type NaTMO<sub>2</sub> materials.</div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S1572665724005332"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S157266572400540X"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion battery</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>NaNi1</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>3Fe1</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>3Mn1</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>3O2</span></div><div id="k0030" class="keyword"><span>Zr doping</span></div><div id="k0035" class="keyword"><span>Structure stability</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st015" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0005">Since the completion of the first industrial revolution, the demand for primary energy has been increasing rapidly, making the development of new energy sources and efficient energy utilization a contemporary hot topic <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>. Recently, lithium-ion batteries have been successfully commercialized and have come to dominate the energy storage, the energy storage, electric vehicles, and portable devices sectors. However, lithium resources are relatively scarce and unevenly distributed, revealing inherent shortcomings for large-scale energy storage systems (LSEESs). Sodium-ion batteries, analogous to lithium-ion batteries, are particularly suitable for LSEESs due to their extensive geographical distribution and abundant resource reserves <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>. Furthermore, the manufacturing process of sodium-ion batteries is highly compatible with that of lithium-ion batteries, significantly reducing production costs and offering high potential for industrialization <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">The cathode material is a critical component of ion-based batteries. Prominent candidates for cathode materials in sodium-ion batteries include transition metal oxides <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, polyanionic compounds <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, and Prussian blue analogs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>. Among these, expectations for the commercialization of transition metal oxides (Na<em><sub>x</sub></em>TMO<sub>2</sub>, where TM&nbsp;=&nbsp;transition metal) are extremely ambitious owing to their high theoretical capacity, excellent electrical conductivity, fast diffusion kinetics, and compatibility with established battery manufacturing infrastructure <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>. The O3-type and P2-type structures are the two common structures found in Na<em><sub>x</sub></em>TMO<sub>2</sub>. When x&nbsp;=&nbsp;1 in Na<em><sub>x</sub></em>TMO<sub>2</sub>, the material exhibits an O3-type structure, which can accommodate more Na<sup>+</sup> compared to the P2-type structure (x&nbsp;&lt;&nbsp;0.7), indicating a higher theoretical specific capacity <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>. However, O3-type Na<em><sub>x</sub></em>TMO<sub>2</sub> still faces critical challenges hindering its commercialization: Firstly, poor air stability significantly increases production and transportation costs and poses a risk of electrochemical performance degradation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>. Secondly, the complex structural evolution during sodiation/desodiation processes leads to poor structural stability, deteriorating sodium storage performance <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. For the former, microstructure modulation <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, surface modification <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, and elemental doping <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a> are effective strategies to improve air stability. For the latter, elemental doping is widely recognized as a robust method for maintaining structural stability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>. For instance, Sun et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a> proposed substituting Na<sup>+</sup> in NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NNFMO) with Ca<sup>2+</sup>. ICP and XRD refinement results indicated that Ca<sup>2+</sup> successfully replaced Na<sup>+</sup>, generating Na vacancies and resulting in a larger interlayer spacing in the alkali layers, which accelerates Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion. In situ XRD analysis demonstrated that NNFMO experienced a reversible â€œO3-P3-O3â€³ phase transition during charge and discharge. In addition, Ca<sup>2+</sup> doping effectively widened the stable voltage range of the P3 phase, leading to superior material recoverability, which strongly supports long-term operational stability. As a result, the prepared Na<sub>0.9</sub>Ca<sub>0.05</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> electrode exhibited an initial discharge capacity of 116.1 mAh/g at a current density of 1C and a capacity retention of 91.8&nbsp;% after 200 cycles, while the capacity retention of the pristine sample was only 67&nbsp;% after 200 cycles. Additionally, the Na<sub>0.9</sub>Ca<sub>0.05</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> electrode demonstrated excellent rate performance (86.2 mAh/g at 10C), attributed to the effective improvement in structural reversibility and the expanded d-spacing of the alkali metal layers due to Ca<sup>2+</sup> doping. Besides, Wang et al. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0280" name="bb0280" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0280"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a> proposed a high-valence ion doping strategy by introducing Ta<sup>5+</sup> into O3-type NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, which forms stronger TM-O bonds with oxygen compared to transition metal elements (Ni, Fe, Mn, etc.). XRD results showed that Ta doping raised the phase transition voltage from O3 to P3 to 3.2&nbsp;V, improving phase transition reversibility. Compared to the pristine sample, theoretical calculations indicated that the introduction of Ta<sup>5+</sup> widened the spacing of the alkali metal layers, effectively reduced the activation energy barrier of Na<sup>+</sup> and decreased the band gap. As a result, the NFM-Ta0.01 electrode achieved a capacity retention of 80.15&nbsp;% after 200 cycles at 1C, significantly higher than that of the original sample (35.44&nbsp;%).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">Inspired by the selection of doping elements mentioned above, we proposed introducing high-valence metal elements into the structure to form strong TM-O bonds, leading to shorter TM-O bond lengths as well as enhanced TM-O bond energies, thereby improving the structural stability of O3-type materials and enhancing phase transition reversibility. Herein, we introduced trace amounts of Zr<sup>4+</sup> into O3-NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> to prepare a series of materials, NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>Zr<em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>2</sub> (<em>x</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 0.002, 0.004, 0.006, 0.008). First, XRD results showed that the introduction of Zr suppressed the formation of the NiO phase. Second, Zr doping enhanced the structure stability, with a discharge capacity of 113.8&nbsp;mAh/g at 1&nbsp;C and an increase in capacity retention from 53.66&nbsp;% in the original sample to 67.54&nbsp;% in the modified sample. Finally, XRD, SEM, and TEM measurements demonstrated that Zr doping effectively improved structural stability during the cycling process.</div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st020" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="s0015"><h3 id="st025" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Synthesis of samples.</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (denoted as NNFMO-bare) and NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>Zr<sub>0.00</sub><em><sub>x</sub></em>O<sub>2</sub> (denoted as NNFMZO-<em>x</em>, <em>x</em> &nbsp;=&nbsp;2000, 4000, 6000, and 8000) samples were synthesized via the solid-phase method. Typically, a mixture of NiO, FeO, and MnO powders with a molar ratio of 1:1:1 was added to a blender with a specific amount of Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> and blended for 1&nbsp;h at 40&nbsp;rpm. Then, the mixture was transferred to a muffle furnace. First, the temperature was raised to 500&nbsp;â„ƒ at a rate of 5&nbsp;â„ƒ&nbsp;min<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and sintered for 5&nbsp;h. Subsequently, the temperature was raised to 890&nbsp;â„ƒ at a rate of 5&nbsp;â„ƒ&nbsp;min<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and sintered for 12&nbsp;h. Finally, the material was cooled down to room temperature at a cooling rate of 10&nbsp;â„ƒ&nbsp;min<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, and the target NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> was obtained. As for NNFMZO-<em>x</em>, the synthetic procedures are consistent with those for the preparation of NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, except for the varying amounts of ZrO<sub>2</sub> added.</div></section><section id="s0020"><h3 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Structure characterizations.</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">X-ray diffraction (XRD) was employed to confirm the crystal structure of the as-prepared samples over the angular range from 10 to 80Â°. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) was conducted to explore the elemental ratios and determine the molecular formula of the samples. Field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) accompanied by the Energy Dispersive Spectrometer (EDS) was utilized to observe the micromorphology and element distribution of the pristine and cycled samples. The microstructure of the pristine and cycled samples was determined by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM).</div></section><section id="s0025"><h3 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Electrochemical test.</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">The cathode electrode was prepared by employing active material, PVDF, and acetylene black in a mass ratio of 8:1:1. First, the cathode material, acetylene black, and PVDF were mixed in a fixed mass ratio and quickly ground in a mortar for 5&nbsp;min until well mixed. Second, NMP was added to the mixture, and the powder was dispersed to obtain a homogeneous cathode slurry. Then, the slurry was scraped onto Al foil with a thickness of 120&nbsp;Âµm. Subsequently, the electrode was dried in a vacuum oven at 120&nbsp;Â°C for 12&nbsp;h. Finally, the cathodes were prepared by cutting the dried electrode into round pieces with a diameter of 14&nbsp;mm. The average mass loading of the cathodes were 1.0â€“2.0&nbsp;mg/cm<sup>2</sup>. The half cells were assembled by employing the glass fiber(as separator), metallic sodium(as anode), cathode, and electrolyte(1&nbsp;M NaPF<sub>6</sub> dissolved in EC/PC with 5&nbsp;vol% FEC additive). The galvanostatic chargeâ€“discharge test was conducted on a LAND test device with the voltage range of 2.0â€“4.0&nbsp;V (vs. Na<sup>+</sup>/Na).</div></section></section><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0035">To analyze the crystal structure of the samples, X-ray powder diffraction was conducted, and the results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(a). The XRD patterns of all samples can be indexed to the <em>Î±</em>-NaFeO<sub>2</sub> structure with an R-3m space group. The shapes of the characteristic peaks of the doped samples with different Zr contents are consistent with NNFMO-bare, and the differences in the intensities of the characteristic peaks are not significant, suggesting that the influence of Zr doping is negligible for crystal structure. In addition, compared to the undoped samples, the XRD diffraction peaks of the doped samples are not significantly shifted due to the low concentration of Zr doping. Additionally, the XRD patterns of the as-prepared samples appear at âˆ¼37.25Â° and âˆ¼43.25Â° as the characteristic peaks of NiO (PDF#89-7131), which belong to (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) and (2&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) crystal planes, respectively. Furthermore, the XRD spectra are locally enlarged within the angular region of 42.6â€“43.8Â°, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>(b). In comparison with the NNFMO-bare, the XRD patterns of the Zr-doped samples show a reduced intensity of the characteristic peaks of the (2&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) crystal plane corresponding to NiO. This suggests that the introduction of Zr to NNFMO-bare contributes to the suppression of NiO phase generation.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr1.jpg" height="267" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (209KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (209KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (a) XRD patterns of NNFMO-bare, NNFMZO-2000, NNFMZO-4000, NNFMZO-6000, and NNFMZO-8000. The orange underlined border area inside the picture is the partially enlarged area. (b) Partially enlarged XRD pattern in the angular range of 42.6â€“43.8Â°. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">Further, XRD measurements were employed to analyze the tendency of NiO in the samples synthesized at different sintering temperatures (doped with Zr at a concentration of 6000&nbsp;ppm). As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>, the intensity of the characteristic peaks of the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;2) crystal plane attributed to NiO increases gradually with the increase in sintering temperature, indicating that higher sintering temperatures favor the generation of NiO.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0045">The morphologies of NNFMO-bare, NNFMZO-2000, NNFMZO-4000, NNFMZO-6000, and NNFMZO-8000 are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(aâ€“e). NNFMO-bare consists of irregular flake particles with diameters of 500&nbsp;nm to 2&nbsp;Î¼m stacked into columnar particles with a length of 200&nbsp;nm. Interestingly, as the doping concentration of Zr increases, the primary particles transform from irregular flake particles to square flake particles without any significant change in size. This phenomenon may be attributed to the fact that the addition of Zr changes the materialâ€™s surface energy, which in turn changes the morphology of the primary particles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0285" name="bb0285" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0285"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>(f-f5) shows the EDS maps of the NNFMZO-6000 sample, which suggest that Na, Ni, Fe, Mn, and Zr are uniformly distributed, indicating the successful introduction of Zr into the material. The elemental composition of the synthesized samples was determined by ICP testing. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0050" name="bs0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>, the compositions are Na<sub>0.999</sub>Ni<sub>0.335</sub>Fe<sub>0.332</sub>Mn<sub>0.334</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>1.002</sub>Ni<sub>0.333</sub>Fe<sub>0.334</sub>Mn<sub>0.334</sub>Zr<sub>0.002</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>1.001</sub>Ni<sub>0.334</sub>Fe<sub>0.333</sub>Mn<sub>0.333</sub>Zr<sub>0.004</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, Na<sub>0.999</sub>Ni<sub>0.333</sub>Fe<sub>0.334</sub>Mn<sub>0.334</sub>Zr<sub>0.006</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, and Na<sub>1.001</sub>Ni<sub>0.333</sub>Fe<sub>0.333</sub>Mn<sub>0.334</sub>Zr<sub>0.008</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, corresponding to NNFMO-bare, NNFMZO-2000, NNFMZO-4000, NNFMZO-6000, and NNFMZO-8000, respectively. The Na:Ni:Fe:Mn:Zr mole ratios are consistent with predesigned ratios</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr2.jpg" height="195" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (142KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (142KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. SEM images of the (a) NNFMO-bare, (b) NNFMZO-2000, (c) NNFMZO-4000, (d, f) NNFMZO-6000 and (e) NNFMZO-8000. (f1â€“f5) EDS maps of NNFMZO-6000.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0050">Galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements were conducted to test the electrochemical properties of the materials, and the results are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(a) shows the rate capabilities of NNFMO-bare, NNFMZO-2000, NNFMZO-4000, NNFMZO-6000, and NNFMZO-8000. Specifically, the NNFMZO-6000 electrode exhibits superior rate performance with discharge capacities of 160.5, 120, 113.8, 106.6, 93.5 and 84.4&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;C, 0.5&nbsp;C, 1&nbsp;C, 2&nbsp;C, 5&nbsp;C, and 10&nbsp;C, respectively. In comparison, the NNFMO-bare electrode exhibits the poorest rate performance with discharge capacities of 115.1, 110.3, 105.2, 99.2, 88.7 and 77.7&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;C, 0.5&nbsp;C, 1&nbsp;C, 2&nbsp;C, 5&nbsp;C, and 10&nbsp;C, respectively. Notably, the NNFMZO-6000 electrode exhibits a discharge specific capacity of 160.5&nbsp;mAh/g at a current density of 0.1&nbsp;C, which may be attributed to the Zr<sup>4+</sup> doping that effectively regulated the Na-O-TM structure in the material. This regulation of the Na-O-TM structure successfully activates the redox reactions of lattice oxygen, providing the capacity during the charging and discharging processes <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0290" name="bb0290" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0290"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(b, c) show the charge/discharge curves of NNFMO-bare and NNFMZO-6000 at different current densities, respectively. Compared to NNFMO-bare, NNFMZO-6000 shows a more distinct and prolonged discharge plateau.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr3.jpg" height="382" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (470KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (470KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) Rate performance of NNFMO-bare, NNFMZO-2000, NNFMZO-4000, NNFMZO-6000 and NNFMZO-8000. The charge/discharge curves at different rate of (b) NNFMO-bare and (c) NNFMZO-6000. (d) Cycling performance of NNFMO-bare, NNFMZO-2000, NNFMZO-4000, NNFMZO-6000 and NNFMZO-8000 at 1C. Charge/discharge curves at various cycles of (e) NNFMO-bare and (f) NNFMZO-6000.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">To assess the prolonged operational capability of the synthesized samples, all electrodes were characterized by cycling at 1&nbsp;C. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(d), the NNFMZO-6000 electrode displays the highest capacity retention of 67.54&nbsp;% after 200 cycles, while NNFMZO-2000, NNFMZO-4000, and NNFMZO-8000 exhibited capacity retention of 59.06&nbsp;%, 61.84&nbsp;%, and 64.19&nbsp;%, respectively. As the doping concentration of Zr increases, the capacity retention showes a tendency to increase and then decrease, indicating that the optimal doping concentration is 6000&nbsp;ppm. Without modification, the capacity retention of the NNFMO-bare electrode was only 53.66&nbsp;% after 200 cycles, which is attributed to the irreversible structural phase transition that occurs in the material during the charging/discharging process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>. This suggests that regardless of the amount of Zr addition, the structural stability of the material can be improved, thereby increasing the capacity retention after long-term cycling. This conclusion will be demonstrated later by the characterization of XRD, SEM, and TEM. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(e,f) show the charge/discharge curves of NNFMO-bare and NNFMZO-6000 electrodes at different numbers of cycles, respectively. Compared to NNFMO-bare, NNFMZO-6000 shows less polarization during charging and discharging, indicating that the introduction of Zr effectively suppresses the polarization of the material during desodiation/sodiation. Interestingly, the NNFMZO-6000 shows a new platform around 2.6&nbsp;V, which is attributed to the phase transformation from P3 to O3â€² <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0295" name="bb0295" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0295"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>. As the cycles progress, the platform becomes less obvious after 20 cycles. Finally, the platform disappears completely after 40 cycles. In conclusion, the enhanced capacity and cycling stability are mainly attributed to the activation of the oxygen redox reaction as well as the improvement of structural stability due to Zr doping.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0060">The different Na storage behaviors between NNFMO-bare and NNFMZO-6000 were explored using the corresponding dQ/dV profiles in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>. For NNFMO-bare, distinct redox peaks (3.0/2.7&nbsp;V) can be observed, which may be contributed to the Ni<sup>4+</sup>/Ni<sup>2+</sup> via Ni<sup>3+</sup> redox process <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>. With increasing current density, the oxidation and reduction peak potentials shift towards the polarization direction. In contrast, one oxidation peak and two reduction peaks appear in the dQ/dV curves of NNFMZO-6000 charged/discharged at 0.1&nbsp;C. The O/P mixed phase appearing at 2.6&nbsp;V triggers an additional reduction peak <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>. Specifically, the oxidizing voltage platform difference of NNFMO-bare between the current density of 0.1C and 10C is 638&nbsp;mV, which is higher than that of NNFMZO-6000 (544&nbsp;mV), demonstrating that Zr doping suppresses the polarization of materials at high current density. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(c, d) show the dQ/dV curves at different cycles. Compared to NNFMO-bare, significant redox peaks can be detected in the curves of NNFMZO-6000 even after 200 cycles. Conversely, no obvious peaks can be found in the curves of NNFMO-bare after 200 cycles, suggesting that Zr doping effectively maintains the structural integrity of the material over long-term operation. Additionally, both materials exhibit a degree of polarization during cycling.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr4.jpg" height="488" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (407KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (407KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. The dQ/dV curves of (a) NNFMO-bare and (b) NNFMZO-6000 at different current densities. The dQ/dV curves of (c) NNFMO-bare and (d) NNFMZO-6000 at different cycles.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065">XRD analysis was conducted to explore the structural changes in the cycled materials. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a> shows a comparison of the XRD patterns of the two electrodes after cycling. The intensities of the diffraction peaks in both samples weaken after cycling. The characteristic peaks of (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;3) and (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;4), which represent the layered structure, remain clearly observable. Moreover, the characteristic peak located at âˆ¼43Â°, belonging to NiO, still appears. This indicates that the repeated deintercalation/intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> collapses the layered structure. Meanwhile, side reactions between the material and electrolyte continue to occur on the electrode surface during cycling process. All of these lead to degradation of the layered structure of the material. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(b), compared to NNFMO-bare, the characteristic peak of the (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;4) crystal plane belonging to NNFMZO-6000 appears at âˆ¼41.75Â°, which is significantly higher, demonstrating that the layered structure is maintained more integrally with Zr doping. Additionally, the characteristic peak appearing near 65Â° belongs to the aluminum foil.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr5.jpg" height="262" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (145KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (145KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a) XRD patterns of NNFMO-bare and NNFMZO-6000 after the 200th cycle. (b) Partially enlarged XRD pattern in the angular range of 41â€“42Â°.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">To visually observe the erosion of the cycled material's surface morphology by the electrolyte, SEM measurements were conducted and the images are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>. The surface of NNFMO-bare in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a> (a, b) becomes rough after cycling, and the division between particles becomes blurred. The particle surface of the material has been damaged due to the Na<sup>+</sup> deintercalation-intercalation process as well as corrosion by the electrolyte. In contrast, in the SEM images of NNFMZO-6000, the demarcation between particles is still obvious, and the particle surface is smooth, suggesting that Zr doping can protect the material from the erosion of the electrolyte, ultimately benefiting the cycling stability of the material.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr6.jpg" height="466" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (259KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (259KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0030"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. SEM images of NNFMO-bare and NNFMZO-6000 (a, c) before and (b, d) after cycling.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0075">TEM measurements were employed to directly characterize the crystal structure of both pristine and cycled materials. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(a) shows the HRTEM images of pristine NNFMO-bare. The distinct (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) lattice fringes with an interlayer spacing of 0.2617&nbsp;nm can be well detected, corresponding to the XRD result. However, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(b) exhibits the distorted lattice fringes, demonstrating that the crystal structure of NNFMO-bare was damaged during the cycling. In contrast, clear lattice fringes are observed in the TEM images of both pristine and cycled NNFMZO-6000, indicating that Zr doping effectively maintains the layer structure. Additionally, the d-spacing indexed to the (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) plane reduces from 0.2629&nbsp;nm to 0.2605&nbsp;nm after cycling, demonstrating compression of the layer structure during the long-term cycling. Furthermore, compared to pristine NNFMO-bare, the d-spacing of (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;1) lattice fringes increases from 0.2617&nbsp;nm to 0.2629&nbsp;nm with Zr doping, indicating an increased d-spacing of the material and broadened Na<sup>+</sup> transport paths. In conclusion, Zr doping effectively preventes the decay of the material's layer structure, thereby explaining the optimal long-cycle stability of NNFMZO-6000.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr7.jpg" height="623" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (505KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (505KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0035"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. HRTEM images of NNFMO-bare and NNFMZO-6000 (a, c) before and (b, d) after cycling.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st045" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">NNFMZO-x (x&nbsp;=&nbsp;0, 2000, 4000, 6000, 8000) series materials were synthesized using the solid-state method. Firstly, Zr doping widens the interlayer spacing, facilitating Na+ transport channels, thereby accelerates kinetics and enhances discharge capacity. Secondly, Zr doping improves the structural stability during prolonged charge/discharge cycles, inhibiting layer structure degradation. Consequently, NNFMZO-6000 demonstrates superior electrochemical performance, achieving a discharge specific capacity of 113.8&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 1&nbsp;C with 67.54&nbsp;% capacity retention after 200 cycles. XRD and TEM results demonstrate that Zr doping preserves the material structure during cycle. Overall, our study presents an effective strategy for modifying sodium-ion layered oxide materials for industrial applications.</div></section><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st050" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><strong>Changlong Lei:</strong> Writing â€“ review &amp; editing, Writing â€“ original draft, Investigation, Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Yuming Liu:</strong> Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Weijia Tang:</strong> Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Yunjiao Li:</strong> Methodology. <strong>Yi Cheng:</strong> Methodology. <strong>Guangsheng Huo:</strong> Methodology. <strong>Zhenjiang He:</strong> Supervision, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization.</div></section></div><section id="coi005"><h2 id="st055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ak005"><h2 id="st060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgments</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0095"><span id="gp005">Central South University Innovation-Driven Research Programme</span> (Grant No.<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2023CXQD053</span></span></a>), <span id="gp010">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (Grant No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gp010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">52274310</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0050"><h2 id="st070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Supplementary data</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105">The following are the Supplementary data to this article:</div></section><section id="s0060"><h2 id="st080" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix C. Supplementary data</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">The following are the Supplementary data to this article:<span class="display"><span class="e-component e-component-mmc1" id="m0005"><span class="article-attachment u-margin-xs-bottom"><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1572665724005356-mmc1.docx" target="_blank" download="" title="Download Word document (242KB)"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" width="20" class="icon icon-text-document"><path d="M1 10v108h57.22L91 85.09V10H1m80 70.96L54.07 108H11V20h70v60.96zM43 100h10V80h20V70H43v30M25 32h42v10H25V32zm0 18h42v10H25V50z"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download Word document (242KB)</span></span></span></a></span><span class="captions text-s"><span><p><span class="label">Supplementary Data 1</span>. </p></span></span></span></span></div></section></div></div><div class="related-content-links u-display-none-from-md"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-small" type="button"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Recommended articles</span></span></button></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="bi005"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="bs005"><ol class="references" id="reference-links-bs005"><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0005" id="ref-id-b0005" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="h0005"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">A. Cao</div><div id="ref-id-h0025" class="title text-m">Recent advances and prospects of layered transition metal oxide cathodes for sodium-ion batteries</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans">Energy 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (6)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2095495625002323"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Design strategies for fast-charging multiphase Na-ion layered cathodes: Dopant selection via computational high-throughput screening</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Energy Chemistry</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">For the advancement of fast-charging sodium-ion batteries (SIBs), the synthesis of cutting-edge cathode materials with superior structural stability and enhanced Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics is imperative. Multiphase layered transition metal oxides (LTMOs), which leverage the synergistic properties of two distinct monophasic LTMOs, have garnered significant attention; however, their efficacy under fast-charging conditions remains underexplored. In this study, we developed a high-throughput computational screening framework to identify optimal dopants that maximize the electrochemical performance of LTMOs. Specifically, we evaluated the efficacy of 32 dopants based on P2/O3-type Mn/Fe-based Na<em><sub>x</sub></em>Mn<sub>0.5</sub>Fe<sub>0.5</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NMFO) cathode material. Multiphase LTMOs satisfying criteria for thermodynamic and structural stability, minimized phase transitions, and enhanced Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion were systematically screened for their suitability in fast-charging applications. The analysis identified two dopants, Ti and Zr, which met all predefined screening criteria. Furthermore, we ranked and scored dopants based on their alignment with these criteria, establishing a comprehensive dopant performance database. These findings provide a robust foundation for experimental exploration and offer detailed guidelines for tailoring dopants to optimize fast-charging SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352492825010359"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A high rate and stability O3-type cathode material based on a Y-doped NaNi&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; matrix</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Materials Today Communications</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0070">In this study, the positive electrode material NaNi<sub>1/3-x</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>Y<sub>x</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NFM-Y x, xâ€¯=â€¯0, 0.01, 0.02) was successfully prepared. Structural and morphological characterizations such as XRD, XPS, and EDS confirmed the successful doping of Y into the material. Y<sup>3â€¯+</sup> substitution reduced the Mn<sup>3+</sup>/Mn<sup>4+</sup> ratio in NFM materials and suppressed Jahn-Teller deformation. Owing to the stronger bonding energy of the Y-O bond, the crystal structure becomes more stable, inhibits the slip of the transition metal layer, and prevents the occurrence of irreversible phase transitions, thereby enhancing the cycling properties of the material and enabling micro-regulation of the crystal structure. Meanwhile, the sodium ion-diffusing layer broadens after Y doping, which significantly increases the sodium ion diffusion ability of the material. Electrochemical tests showed that NFM-Y 0.01 exhibited a discharge specific capacity as high as 179 mAhg<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.2â€¯C. At 1â€¯C and 5â€¯C, the initial capacities of NFM-Y 0.01 were 131.5 mAhg<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 127.4 mAhg<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively, and after 200 cycles, the corresponding cycling retention rates increased by 9.6â€¯% and 12.8â€¯% compared to the matrix material.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2405829725002120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Towards high-performance sodium-ion batteries: A comprehensive review on Na&lt;inf&gt;x&lt;/inf&gt;Ni&lt;inf&gt;y&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;z&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;1âˆ’(&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;y&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;+&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;z&lt;/inf&gt;&lt;inf&gt;)&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; cathode materials</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Energy Storage Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara021">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are potential candidates for next-generation grid-scale energy storage owing to their safety as well as the abundance of sodium resources. Further progress in SIB technology demands the advancement of cathode materials with outstanding performance. Among various cathode materials, layered transition metal oxides based on Ni, Fe, and Mn (NaNFM) have recently received great attention by combining the positive features of each of them. This review focuses on the most current developments in the study and design of NaNFM (Na<em><sub>x</sub></em>Ni<em><sub>y</sub></em>Fe<em><sub>z</sub></em>Mn<sub>1âˆ’(<em><sub>y</sub></em>+</sub><em><sub>z</sub></em><sub>)</sub>O<sub>2</sub>) as a cathode material for SIBs, including synthesis methods, crystal structure/structural evolution during chargeâ€“discharging, and the effect of different molar ratios. Adjusting the transition elements enables formation in several phases that promote Na-ion diffusion, resulting in high-rate capability and cycle stability. Moreover, key strategies to improve the electrochemical performance through doping and surface modifications are discussed. Future optimization of these materials shows potential for enormous opportunities for implementing cost-effective and high-performance energy -storage technologies.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352492824028137"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Effect of increasing alkali layer spacing on the performance of O3-NaNi&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; cathode materials</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Materials Today Communications</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-3-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-3" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0060">O3-Na<sub>1-x</sub>Ca<sub>x/2</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NaCNFMx, x=0, 0.05, 0.1, 0.15) was prepared by doping calcium ions and replacing the sodium sites in the NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NaNFM) material using ball milling spray. XRD, SEM and XPS results demonstrated that the calcium element was successfully embedded in the lattice. The electrochemical performance of NaCNFM0.1 is the best when the doping amount of calcium ion is 0.1. The sodium diffusion coefficient of NaCNFM0.1 cathode material after 3 cycles is 1.67Ã—10<sup>âˆ’14</sup> cm<sup>2</sup>/s. The first specific discharge capacity at 1â€¯C is 121.1â€¯mAh/g. Even at the high current density of 5â€¯C, the 200cycles capacity of 103.6â€¯mAh/g is much higher than NaNFM's 95.2â€¯mAh/g, and the capacity retention rate is as high as 91.5â€¯%. Ex-situ XRD and SEM analyses manifested that the moderate amount of calcium doping improved the stability of the layered structure. These results show that the cathode material has great application potential.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0167273824002662"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Effect of the position of Mg replacing Ni on O3-NaNi&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; on the structural stability of cathode materials</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Solid State Ionics</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-4-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-4" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0060">O3-NaNi<sub>1/3</sub>Fe<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub> (NaNFM) materials are susceptible to complex phase transitions during electrical cycling leading to poor structural, capacity retention and multiplicity properties. These drawbacks hinder the application of NaNFM in sodium-ion batteries. Here, Mg<sup>2+</sup> with larger ionic radius was used to dope its transition metal layer Ni site. The effects of Mg<sup>2+</sup> doped NaNFM crystal structure and transition metal valence states on its electrochemical properties were investigated by XRD, SEM, and XPS. The capacity retention of NaNMFM-0.02 (84.05&nbsp;%) was higher than that of NaNFM (73&nbsp;%) after 200&nbsp;cycles of the material at 5C. In addition, NaNMFM-0.02 achieved a first discharge specific capacity of 146.5 mAh/g at high voltage. Based on structural and electrochemical analyses, this improvement is attributed to the fact that magnesium acts as a â€œpillarâ€ to stabilize the crystal structure of NaNFM, while magnesium doping reduces the Jahn-Teller effect. As a result, the material has better electrochemical properties.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.jpcc.4c08703" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Understanding the New Crucial Role of a Calcium Ion as a Pillar Dopant in Stabilizing O3-Type Na[Ni&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Fe&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;Mn&lt;inf&gt;1/3&lt;/inf&gt;]O&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt; Cathodes</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Journal of Physical Chemistry C</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul></div></div></section></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S1572665724005356"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">Â© 2024 Elsevier B.V. All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right u-padding-s-top"><aside class="RelatedContent u-clr-grey8" aria-label="Related content"><section class="RelatedContentPanel u-margin-s-bottom"><header id="recommended-articles-header"     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
